awd_titl_txt: Construction of the 'Other': Development, Consequences, and Applied Implications of Racism, Prejudice and Discrimination
awd_abstract_narration:
Deep divisions between majority/minority groups, overt violence and hate crimes, and increasing social inequities around the world are pervasive and exacerbated by a global pandemic. This award will support the travel and mentoring of up to 30 emerging scholars from underrepresented minority (URM) groups to attend the Society for Research on Child Development 2022 Special Topics Conference entitled Construction of the “Other”: Theory, Research, and Applied Implications of Racism, Prejudice, and Discrimination and to reconnect at the SRCD Biennial Conference. The special topics conference will bring together scholars to discuss theories and research on: a) how children develop prejudice, racist attitudes and conceptions of in- and out-group, b) the health and developmental consequences of experiencing bias and discrimination, and c) the policy and intervention programs aimed at reducing such prejudice. High quality speaker presentations, symposia, and posters will summarize the state-of-the-art theories, research and methodologies in this area. 

The conference will spur increased efforts by researchers to address the major gaps in theory, research, policy, and intervention on prejudice, bias, and discrimination. Moreover, the conference will have far-reaching impact to our communities and inform important global movements  and crises. First, the conference sends a strong message to the public regarding the serious efforts by major research organizations focusing on child health to address the challenges related to racism and prejudice. Second, the conference will serve as a springboard for translation to policy. And third, a mentoring program will provide much needed training for URM junior scholars to spur broader diversity to address the major gaps in theory, research, policy, and intervention on prejudice, bias, and discrimination. This effort will support the next generation of scholars to acquire rigorous scientific training and expertise on this topic and to become a resource to provide evidence-based practice recommendations to community entities facing the social challenges of racism, prejudice and discrimination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Carlo successfully completed the NSF mentoring program grant entitled, Construction of the Other: The Development, Consequences, and Applications of Racism, Prejudice, and Discrimination Conference Grant. The grant provided mentoring and conference travel support to 30 graduate students from underrepresented groups. The mentees were matched with one of 10 senior scholars of color mentors. Mentors and mentees were provided travel support to attend two professional research conferences and incentivized to work together on scientific projects. 

The mentors and mentees attended the Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD) Special Topics conference entitled, Construction of the Other: The Development, Consequences, and Applications of Racism, Prejudice, and Discrimination, held in Rio Grande, Puerto Rico in May of 2022. One year later, they reunited at the Society for Research in Child Development conference in Salt Laker City, Utah. 

During these conferences, the grant also provided support for informational and professional development sessions targeting the 30 graduate students of color to provide advice and support. The mentees attended the conference, presented their research, attended joint events, and developed a mentoring and career plan with their senior mentors. 

Several of the mentees reported building strong connections with their senior mentors and developing collaborative research projects. For many of the graduate students, the opportunity to connect with a distinguished senior scholar of color was a first because many are attending predominantly White colleges and universities. For others, this was their experience at a scientific conference and provided the opportunity to build their network and support for their professional development. During the support period, several of the mentees reported the successful submission or acceptance of six papers to peer-review research journals and 16 research presentations at professional scientific conferences. 

The project support and opportunities afforded to these 30 graduate students from underrepresented groups will enhance their success in graduating from theirr Ph.D. programs, becoming well-trained research scientists, and entering and diversifying the science workforce.
